In 2006, Cameron expressed his desire to create sequels for Avatar if the first film was successful.
Cameron announced the first two sequels in 2010 following the widespread success of the original Avatar.
The filming process for Avatar: Fire and Ash began simultaneously with Avatar 3 in August 2017.
In September 2017, the filming location for Avatar: Fire and Ash moved to Wellington, New Zealand.
The filming process for Avatar: Fire and Ash ended in late September 2020 after three years of shooting.
With an estimated budget of $350–460 million, Avatar: Fire and Ash is one of the most expensive films ever made.
The film grossed $2.320 billion worldwide, making it the highest-grossing film of 2022 and the third-highest-grossing film of all time.
The film received generally positive reviews from critics, who praised the visual effects and technical achievements but criticized the plot and runtime.
Three further sequels are in production, with the next film, Avatar: Fire and Ash set to be released in December 2025.
The film premiered at the Odeon Luxe Leicester Square in London on December 6, 2022.
The film was released in the United States on December 16.
The National Board of Review named The Way of Water one of the top-ten films of 2022.
The American Film Institute named The Way of Water one of the top-ten films of 2022.

The filming of the Avatar sequel films in New Zealand had been postponed indefinitely in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, but production remained in Los Angeles according to Landau's announcement on March 17, 2020.

While the filming of the Avatar sequel films in New Zealand had been postponed indefinitely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, virtual production continued in Manhattan Beach, California according to recent updates.

While the filming of the Avatar sequel films in New Zealand had been postponed indefinitely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, visual effects continued at Weta Digital in Wellington according to recent updates.

Landau announced on March 17, 2020, that the filming of the Avatar sequel films in New Zealand had been postponed indefinitely due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

According to Landau's announcement on March 17, 2020, production of the Avatar sequel films remained in Los Angeles while filming in New Zealand was postponed indefinitely due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

James Cameron, the director of Avatar: Fire and Ash, resumed filming on June 16, 2020, in New Zealand after a 2-week government-supervised isolation period with 55 other crew members who had also traveled to New Zealand. This marks the first major Hollywood blockbuster to resume production following postponement due to the pandemic.

Jon Landau, a producer of Avatar: Fire and Ash, posted a picture on Instagram with James Cameron and Kate Winslet (Cameron's character in the movie) on June 1, 2020, signaling their return to New Zealand for filming. This was followed by a government-supervised isolation period for both Cameron and Landau, as well as other crew members.

Cameron, Landau, and 55 other crew members traveled to New Zealand for the production of Avatar: Fire and Ash due to its favorable filming conditions amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. They completed their 2-week isolation period in a hotel in Wellington before commencing filming.

Cliff Curtis, a New Zealand actor, was cast to play Tonowari in Avatar: Fire and Ash. This is his fourth collaboration with James Cameron, having previously acted in The Dark Horse (2014), Avatar (2009), and Titanic (1997).
Duane Evans Jr., a New Zealand actor, was cast to play Roxto in Avatar: Fire and Ash. This is his first collaboration with James Cameron.

The New Zealand production of Avatar: Fire and Ash hired 46 New Zealand cast members, including Cliff Curtis and Duane Evans Jr., as well as almost 800 extras, and 36 apprentices and interns. This highlights the significant employment opportunities generated by film productions in New Zealand.
In July 2022, the New Zealand Film Commission disclosed that the Avatar sequels had received over NZ$140 million worth of public funding through the country's Screen Production Grant.
The Avatar sequels received over NZ$140 million worth of public funding through the New Zealand Film Commission's Screen Production Grant.
By comparison, The Hobbit trilogy (2012–2014) had received NZ$161 million in film subsidies.

many positive reviews have advocated seeing the film in as large a format as possible, highlighting the importance of viewing this visual spectacle in a maximized format.
according to Owen Gleiberman's review, the film's combat sequences are miraculously sustained and contribute to its status as a 'dizzyingly spectacular sequel'.
according to Owen Gleiberman's review, the film's underwater sequences are 'experiential', a term which emphasizes their immersive nature.

according to David Sim's review, the film gets off to a slow start as it updates the audience on 'the past decade-plus of Pandoran life'. This relationship highlights the initial pacing issues in relation to the series' development.

node_2: discussions in creature design and speculative biology
edge: according to Darren Naish, the film's 'new delights...in the alien world of Pandora' will remain a 'mainstay of discussions in creature design and speculative biology for some time yet'. This relationship emphasizes the film's importance in these fields.

node_2: substantial enough to justify the length
edge: Some critics felt that the film was excessively long, and that the story was not substantial enough to justify the length.

Anthony Lane opined: "The film is more than three hours long, some of it dangerously close to dawdling; not until the final third does Cameron apply the whip and remind us that, in the choreographing of action sequences, he remains unsurpassed."
The Guardian critic Peter Bradshaw was critical of the 'scathingly bland plot' and noted that, despite the shift in setting, 'there isn't a single interesting visual image'.

node_2: hollywood visionaries who actually merits that much-abused term
edge: Los Angeles Times critic Justin Chang hailed Cameron as 'one of the few Hollywood visionaries who actually merits that much-abused term'.

Following the box-office success of The Way of Water, Cameron confirmed that both Avatar 4 and Avatar 5 are being developed but have not been officially greenlit. In January 2019, in face of the proposed acquisition of 21st Century Fox by The Walt Disney Company, Disney CEO Bob Iger confirmed that both Avatar 4 and Avatar 5 are being developed but have not been officially greenlit.
